title: Mariners Playoff Analysis
text:
If the rest of the MLB games this season were decided by a coin flip, would the Mariners make the playoffs?

Introduction
Simulates a 2023 season of all 161 games using the Bradley-Terry model.
By repeated simulations, can explore the relationship between talent and season performance.
Talent has been edited so that each team has the same talent. Essentially a 50/50 chance for each game.


Main functions
Read in two functions:

one.simulation.20() performs the simulation
print_standings() prints the division standings of the simulation

Reads in the data:

schedule1 <- read_excel("schedule.xlsx") reads in a two column excel sheet with headers ‘Home’ and ‘Away’ and teams from each game listed below




Read in several packages that I’ll need.

library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
library(MASS)

Also I am adding several helper functions increasefont() and centertitle() that I will use in ggplot2.

increasefont <- function(Size = 18){
  theme(text = element_text(size = Size))
}

decreasefont <- function(Size = 14){
  theme(text = element_text(size = Size))
}

centertitle <- function(Color = "blue"){
    theme(plot.title = 
            element_text(colour = Color, size = 18, 
        hjust = 0.5, vjust = 0.8, angle = 0))
}



One simulation
One simulation assuming a standard deviation of 0.3.

# set.seed(121)
out <- one.simulation.20(0.01)
print_standings(out)

                                                                        
                 AL East    W     L                   NL East    W     L
                 ------------------                   ------------------
           Tampa Bay Rays   88   73       Washington Nationals   85   76
        Baltimore Orioles   85   76              Miami Marlins   80   81
        Toronto Blue Jays   84   77              New York Mets   79   82
         New York Yankees   77   84             Atlanta Braves   73   88
           Boston Red Sox   71   90      Philadelphia Phillies   65   96
                                                                        
                 AL Cent    W     L                   NL Cent    W     L
                 ------------------                   ------------------
           Detroit Tigers   87   74         Pittsburgh Pirates   87   74
       Kansas City Royals   86   75            Cincinnati Reds   85   76
          Minnesota Twins   84   77        St. Louis Cardinals   82   79
        Chicago White Sox   83   78          Milwaukee Brewers   74   87
      Cleveland Guardians   79   82               Chicago Cubs   72   89
                                                                        
                 AL West    W     L                    NL West   W     L
                 ------------------                   ------------------
         Seattle Mariners   90   71           Colorado Rockies   97   64
            Texas Rangers   87   74       Arizona Diamondbacks   93   68
       Los Angeles Angels   79   82        Los Angeles Dodgers   81   80
           Houston Astros   77   84           San Diego Padres   77   84
        Oakland Athletics   74   87       San Francisco Giants   69   92




1000 Simulations
Store the results of 1000 simulated seasons:

all_out <- NULL  
for(j in 1:1000){
  out <- one.simulation.20(0.01)
  out$Simulation <- j
  all_out <- rbind(all_out, out)
}



Talent and probability of making playoffs



Define a new variable Level that is 0 (missed playoffs), 1 (wild-card), or 2 (win division).






Printing percentage of playoffs made from each team over 1000 seasons.


                                                                              
               AL East  Count  Percent                 NL East  Count  Percent
                  --------------------                    --------------------
         Boston Red Sox  419     41.9%           Atlanta Braves  412     41.2%
       New York Yankees  408     40.8%            New York Mets  401     40.1%
         Tampa Bay Rays  404     40.4%            Miami Marlins  392     39.2%
      Baltimore Orioles  393     39.3%    Philadelphia Phillies  388     38.8%
      Toronto Blue Jays  387     38.7%     Washington Nationals  388     38.8%
                                                                              
               AL Cent  Count  Percent                 NL Cent  Count  Percent
                  --------------------                    --------------------
      Chicago White Sox  421     42.1%          Cincinnati Reds  416     41.6%
     Kansas City Royals  395     39.5%        Milwaukee Brewers  408     40.8%
    Cleveland Guardians  389     38.9%             Chicago Cubs  396     39.6%
        Minnesota Twins  383     38.3%       Pittsburgh Pirates  396     39.6%
         Detroit Tigers  381     38.1%      St. Louis Cardinals  394     39.4%
                                                                              
               AL West  Count  Percent                 NL West  Count  Percent
                  --------------------                    --------------------
          Texas Rangers  417     41.7%      Los Angeles Dodgers  421     42.1%
       Seattle Mariners  414     41.4%         San Diego Padres  409     40.9%
         Houston Astros  405     40.5%     Arizona Diamondbacks  399     39.9%
      Oakland Athletics  393     39.3%         Colorado Rockies  395     39.5%
     Los Angeles Angels  391     39.1%     San Francisco Giants  385     38.5%


Level is an ordinal response variable. Using a proportional odds model, model the ordinal response as a function of the team’s talent.
For a range of talent values from -0.9 to 0.9, find the fitted model probability of the three outcomes.

pfit <- polr(Level ~ Talent,
             data = all_out)
DF <- data.frame(Talent = seq(-0.9, 0.9,
                                  length.out = 200))
Prob <- predict(pfit, DF, type = "probs")
DF1 <- DF2 <- DF3 <- DF
DF1$Probability <- Prob[, 3]; DF1$Type <- "Division"
DF2$Probability <- Prob[, 2]; DF2$Type <- "Wild Card"
DF3$Probability <- Prob[, 3] + Prob[, 2]
DF3$Type <- "Playoff"
DFall <- rbind(DF1, DF2, DF3)

Graph of this division, wild card, and playoff probabilities.

ggplot(DFall, aes(Talent, Probability,
                  color = Type)) +
  geom_line() +
  increasefont() +
  ggtitle("Probability of Reaching Different Levels") +
  centertitle()






Talents of wild card teams and division-winners
Construct density estimates of

all teams
teams that win division
teams that get wild card


data1 <- filter(all_out, Wild.Card == 1) %>% 
         mutate(Type = "Wild Card")
data2 <- filter(all_out, Winner.Div == 1) %>% 
  mutate(Type = "Win Division")
data3 <- all_out %>% 
  mutate(Type = "All Teams")

ggplot(rbind(data1, data2, data3), 
       aes(Talent, color = Type)) +
  geom_density(size = 1.5) +
  increasefont() + centertitle() +
  ggtitle("Talent Distributions for Three Types of Teams")






How many games to win?
Find the conditional probability of winning division title, of getting wild card, and making the playoffs given you won X games.

all_out %>% 
  filter(Wins >= 25, Wins <= 45) %>% 
  group_by(Wins) %>% 
  summarize(N = n(), 
            Prob_Div = mean(Winner.Div),
            Prob_WC = mean(Wild.Card),
            .groups = "drop") -> S

Plot smooths of these empirical probabilities.

S %>% 
  ggplot() +
  geom_smooth(aes(Wins, Prob_Div), se = FALSE,
              color = "red",
              method = "loess") +
  geom_smooth(aes(Wins, Prob_WC), se = FALSE,
              color = "blue",
              method = "loess") + 
  geom_smooth(aes(Wins, Prob_Div + Prob_WC),
                  se = FALSE,
              color = "black",
              method = "loess") +
  increasefont() +
  ylab("Probability") +
  annotate(geom = "text", x = 32, y = 0.75,
           label = "Playoffs", size = 7) +
  annotate(geom = "text", x = 40.3, y = 0.75,
           label = "Division", size = 7,
           color = "red") +
  annotate(geom = "text", x = 40.8, y = 0.25,
           label = "Wild Card", size = 7,
           color = "blue") +
  ggtitle("How Many Games Does Team Need to Win?") +
  centertitle()




````

title: 2020 Season Simulation
text:
Introduction
Simulates a 2020 season of 60 games using the Bradley-Terry model.
By repeated simulations, can explore the relationship between talent and season performance.


Main functions
Read in two functions:

one.simulation.20() performs the simulation
print_standings() prints the division standings of the simulation




Read in several packages that I’ll need.

library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
library(MASS)

Also I am adding several helper functions increasefont() and centertitle() that I will use in ggplot2.

increasefont <- function(Size = 18){
  theme(text = element_text(size = Size))
}
centertitle <- function(Color = "blue"){
    theme(plot.title = 
            element_text(colour = Color, size = 18, 
        hjust = 0.5, vjust = 0.8, angle = 0))
}



One simulation
One simulation assuming a standard deviation of 0.3.

set.seed(123)
out <- one.simulation.20(0.3)
print_standings(out)

                             
  AL East  W  L NL East  W  L
  ------------- -------------
      BAL 39 21     NYN 37 23
      TBA 37 23     WAS 30 30
      BOS 36 24     PHI 28 32
      TOR 25 35     MIA 25 35
      NYA 21 39     ATL 22 38
                             
  AL Cent  W  L NL Cent  W  L
  ------------- -------------
      MIN 33 27     CHN 37 23
      KCR 32 28     PIT 33 27
      CHA 32 28     SLN 29 31
      CLE 30 30     CIN 28 32
      DET 29 31     MIL 17 43
                             
  AL West  W  L NL West  W  L
  ------------- -------------
      SEA 40 20     COL 34 26
      HOU 32 28     SDN 33 27
      TEX 26 34     LAN 32 28
      LAA 25 35     ARI 29 31
      OAK 24 36     SFN 25 35




1000 Simulations
Store the results of 1000 simulated seasons:

all_out <- NULL
for(j in 1:1000){
  out <- one.simulation.20(0.3)
  out$Simulation <- j
  all_out <- rbind(all_out, out)
}



Talent and probability of making playoffs
Define a new variable Level that is 0 (missed playoffs), 1 (wild-card), or 2 (win division).

all_out %>% 
  mutate(Level = as.factor(2 * (Winner.Div == 1) +
                 (Wild.Card == 1))) -> all_out

Level is an ordinal response variable. Using a proportional odds model, model the ordinal response as a function of the team’s talent.
For a range of talent values from -0.9 to 0.9, find the fitted model probability of the three outcomes.

pfit <- polr(Level ~ Talent,
             data = all_out)
DF <- data.frame(Talent = seq(-0.9, 0.9,
                                  length.out = 200))
Prob <- predict(pfit, DF, type = "probs")
DF1 <- DF2 <- DF3 <- DF
DF1$Probability <- Prob[, 3]; DF1$Type <- "Division"
DF2$Probability <- Prob[, 2]; DF2$Type <- "Wild Card"
DF3$Probability <- Prob[, 3] + Prob[, 2]
DF3$Type <- "Playoff"
DFall <- rbind(DF1, DF2, DF3)

Graph of this division, wild card, and playoff probabilities.

ggplot(DFall, aes(Talent, Probability,
                  color = Type)) +
  geom_line() +
  increasefont() +
  ggtitle("Probability of Reaching Different Levels") +
  centertitle()






Talents of wild card teams and division-winners
Construct density estimates of

all teams
teams that win division
teams that get wild card


data1 <- filter(all_out, Wild.Card == 1) %>% 
         mutate(Type = "Wild Card")
data2 <- filter(all_out, Winner.Div == 1) %>% 
  mutate(Type = "Win Division")
data3 <- all_out %>% 
  mutate(Type = "All Teams")

ggplot(rbind(data1, data2, data3), 
       aes(Talent, color = Type)) +
  geom_density(size = 1.5) +
  increasefont() + centertitle() +
  ggtitle("Talent Distributions for Three Types of Teams")






How many games to win?
Find the conditional probability of winning division title, of getting wild card, and making the playoffs given you won X games.

all_out %>% 
  filter(Wins >= 25, Wins <= 45) %>% 
  group_by(Wins) %>% 
  summarize(N = n(), 
            Prob_Div = mean(Winner.Div),
            Prob_WC = mean(Wild.Card),
            .groups = "drop") -> S

Plot smooths of these empirical probabilities.

S %>% 
  ggplot() +
  geom_smooth(aes(Wins, Prob_Div), se = FALSE,
              color = "red",
              method = "loess") +
  geom_smooth(aes(Wins, Prob_WC), se = FALSE,
              color = "blue",
              method = "loess") + 
  geom_smooth(aes(Wins, Prob_Div + Prob_WC),
                  se = FALSE,
              color = "black",
              method = "loess") +
  increasefont() +
  ylab("Probability") +
  annotate(geom = "text", x = 32, y = 0.75,
           label = "Playoffs", size = 7) +
  annotate(geom = "text", x = 40.3, y = 0.75,
           label = "Division", size = 7,
           color = "red") +
  annotate(geom = "text", x = 40.8, y = 0.25,
           label = "Wild Card", size = 7,
           color = "blue") +
  ggtitle("How Many Games Does Team Need to Win?") +
  centertitle()

title: Sports Data Analysis and Visualization
text:
This project uses real MLB data to project how the 2023 season could finish. The first step was just using a 50/50 chance for each team to win for the rest of the season and then adding more determining factors as time went on. This program can also be altered to be used with many different types of data to create projections.












Mariners Playoff Analysis












May 31, 2023


Jonna Waage








Resources












May 30, 2023


Jonna Waage








2020 Season Simulation












Jun 27, 2020


Jim Albert
